clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of Magnesium and Alpha Lipoic Acid Supplementation in Reducing Premature Uterine Contractions

brief_summary.textblock: To evaluate whether a combined supplementation of magnesium and lipoic acid is able to significantly reduce the incidence of uterine contractions and related episodes of hospitalization in pregnant women.

detailed_description.textblock:
Primary prevention of preterm labor is based on the early identification of risk factors and on appropriate treatments. Although several drugs are currently used, the identification of effective and safe agents able to improve both maternal and fetal health is still warranted.
In this study the efficacy a formulation based on magnesium and alpha-lipoic acid has been compared with placebo to evaluate the incidence of reduction of preterm delivery.
Three hundred pregnant women at 14-34 weeks of gestation were enrolled and randomly divided to receive a daily single tablet containing magnesium and alpha-lipoic acid supplement or placebo until delivery.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of women with sporadic episodes of preterm uterine contraction
primary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline (beginning of the treatment) until delivery

primary_outcome.measure: Number of women with frequent and persistent episodes of preterm uterine contractions associated with pain
primary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline (beginning of the treatment) until delivery

primary_outcome.measure: Number of women needed for hospital admission for threatened preterm labour
primary_outcome.time_frame: From baseline (beginning of the treatment) until delivery

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 14-34 weeks of gestation
Exclusion Criteria:
- Preexisting diabetes mellitus
- Systolic blood pressure >140mm Hg
- Cancer
- lupus
- hepatitis
- HIV/AIDS
- Diagnosed alcohol or chemical dependency
